intro: Seseli grandivittatum, commonly known as the broad-veined seseli, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided, fern-like leaves. The plant produces small, greenish-yellow flowers arranged in umbels, typical of the family. It thrives in rocky and arid environments, often growing at high altitudes. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a rare and endangered species.
